title: Pune: Symptomatic people, without a test, can take vaccination after recovery | Pune News - Times of India
author: Umesh Isalkar
description: Symptomatic patients without lab-confirmed Covid can take the vaccine after full recovery from the illness, experts from the ICMR's national Covid tas

For those with a lab-confirmed result, the earlier directive - that vaccination is to be deferred by three months - stays effective. Graph These norms, the experts said, apply to all eligible beneficiaries, including those taking a precautionary dose and adolescents in the 15-17 years age bracket. They are also relevant, considering the sizeable number of people recovering from flu-like symptoms at home. A chunk of these individuals may not have taken a Covid test. "The US CDC recommends a Covid shot after recovery from flu-like illness. Chances of reinfection are extremely low in the first three months, hence the norm for deferring the shot by three months. This also helps in judicious use of the vaccines. But if it is not a lab-proven Covid case, the person can take the jab after recovery from the illness," Dr Sanjay Pujari, a member of the task force, said. The ICMR had earlier said in its guidelines a Covid test is not necessary for those who've come in contact with a Covid patient, unless the contact is in the high-risk category (the elderly or people with comorbidities). The government's latest set of screening guidelines has also removed compulsory testing of asymptomatic close contacts. "People with symptoms who haven't undergone a Covid test should get the vaccines only after they have recovered and met the criteria for discontinuing isolation. Those who are close contacts without symptoms should also wait until they meet the criteria (seven-day quarantine) before getting vaccinated," Dr Pujari said. This guidance also applies to people who get Covid-19 before getting their first, second or precautionary dose. "People who have had known Covid exposure should not seek vaccination until their quarantine period of seven days has ended to avoid potentially exposing healthcare personnel and others during the vaccination visit," Dr Pujari added. Maharashtra's Covid task force head, Dr Sanjay Oak, said, "Those who know they are Covid positive should defer vaccination by three months.
